physDesc.p: Five pages typewritten in black ink. Address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page: Mrs. Richard Aldington care of Mrs. Randall, 3 Christchurch Place Hampstead, London, N.W. England. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I have sent you my new book. Perhaps I should say Richard’s book, seeing as how he is the presiding deity over my volume. I trust that you will like it, but I am afraid that you will not. I seem to remember that Richard, after once having praised "polyphonic prose," went back on it, so possibly you will not care for the volume, considering its form. However, such as it is, here it is.

To me came your good letter of what date I cannot say, since you never date them, but the one in which you tell me that Winifred Bryher is not Winifred Bryher. My dear, what a bomb shell! Who on earth is she? My mind does not run easily on the purlieus of "richest men." I have not the ghost of an idea who is rich in England and who is poor. I had an idea that the Duke of Westminster was the richest man in England, but from what you say I can hardly suppose that Winifred is a young peeress. The only other things that I can think of are a cosmopolitan banker and a large, native, good-natured brewer.

But, in either case, I cannot see what that has to do with Winifred, and I regard her self-consciousness on the subject as extremely foolish, and I would write and tell her so, only you tell me that I must not mention it to her.

It is a handicap to be even well off. My father was not the "richest" anywhere, and yet I have had enough trouble as I am in getting people to realize that I may be a decent poet even if I am not starving in a garret. But it can be done I know, and I am happy to say that I think all the newspapers and the people who once regarded me as an amateur because necessity was not howling under my windows have now given up all thoughts of me as anything but a hard-working and serious writer.

Winifred need not hide her name under a bushel. She ought really to rejoice on the added handicap, and as to thinking that anybody would like her only on account of her money – my but that is a snobbish thought! One has known even multi-millionaires and kept one’s head, and, after all, Winifred did not make the money any more than she made her nose. (In confidence, my dear, is she of the race that has a nose, and is that perhaps the difficulty?) She is no more to be courted for that fact than for anything else for which she is not responsible. Anyhow, I cannot help thinking that she would do better if she did not hide under a nom de plume, and anyhow I am quite sure that she should trust me with her real name – a secret which I will promise not to divulge if she does not wish it – and you can assure her that I do not care a button whether she is a charwoman or a princess of the blood royal. For God’s sake tell her that we are Americans, you and I, and these things do not matter.

I think that she has a promise; I think that she needs sympathy and encouragement; I think that you can do her a lot of good. After all, to think that people will care for you anything except your essentials is a form of snobbishness, even if it is a backhanded snobbishness. And don’t let her be a snob. It is a mistake, and if she thinks that I am a snob – Oh Lord, she ought to meet me!

Of course tell her that I will be as nice as possible when she comes to America and do everything to make her stay comfortable. I do not promise to ask her to spend the Winter with me in the fashion that the English love so well, (but that, perhaps, you need not say,) but she can count on me in every possible way. Certainly I owe her a great deal for her interest and all that she is doing for me over there, as she seems to have aroused Mr. Shorter to a violent partisanship on our side which, although it may annoy certain of the younger men, I think cannot fail to do us good. As to Mr. Shorter’s conservatism – what can you expect? The wonder to me is that he sees anything in us at all. He is, however, a kindly, cosmopolitan, well-read gentleman, and, not being Ezra, I approve of not quenching his smoking flax. I am thankful for all the appreciation that we can get, and I never ask impossibilities of the middle aged, or of the conservative papers from which I have received some amusing clippings.
I understand that he is going to write a paper on your Greek translations soon for "The Sphere."

I thought that Winifred’s little article on all of us in "The Saturday Review" was very interesting. I think that she should be a little more explicit as to what we have written, because I do not think that people know us well enough to jump right away at the knowledge that she assumes that they have, and I think she errs on the side of over-exuberance and praise – an unfortunate fault for the subjects of her articles, as over-praise always brings its own antidote in the reader’s mind, just as over-blame does. But these things are slight and few, compared with the many things that she does well and her genuine understanding and enthusiasm.

As to Fletcher, I despair of him. I had a letter from him the day after I had yours, full of carping criticism and somewhat silly violence. He seems to have got it into his head that I am his enemy instead of his friend, I do not know why, but I know him well enough to know that there is never any use in remonstrating by letter. He makes such ridiculous statements, such as that he has not seen any of our crowd since the beginning of the year and then the following, "I feel that I must travel my own track and they theirs." As if one could not see any one who is not writing exactly as one is writing one’s self; In that case, dear Hilda, neither you nor I would see anybody at all. We would live in a charming but icy isolation, contemplating our own navels and gradually folding up inside out.

I regard Fletcher as a purely pathological case. I am fond of him, but I think he is perfectly unsatisfactory, and I confess that this new manner of writing does not give me any pleasure, at least none of the poems that I have seen in this later style have. I did not care for his two contributions to Sadler’s "New Paths." And, by the way, why were you not represented in that volume. Richard said that he had asked you both to contribute. I am afraid that you are hypercritical of your own work. I wish that I were there to give you a jolt and tell you how frightfully good it is, and now that the war news is so good I cannot help thinking that some time or other we shall all meet again and resume the happy intercourse that we had before. Certainly those seven short weeks that we all passed together in 1914 have made all the difference in my life, and certainly you and Richard are among the best friends I have.

It is splendid to know that Richard has such a good job and is out of danger. I have just received word that my nephew has been distin>guishing himself on the firing line, so I feel quite happy. Richard asked me to tell him his name and address, so that in case they were ever together, he might look him up. Here it is: Captain James A. Roosevelt, 302nd Ammunition Train, 77th Division, American Expeditionary Force

I have had a letter from Lawrence which tells me that he has dedicated his last book of poems to me. He seems frightfully blue, and I do not see how he can be otherwise. His prospects certainly are far from bright. It is no use telling him that it is his own fault. His principle is never to bow to the taste of the public, and although I think a certain amount of compromise is necessary, still his attitude is fine if suicidal.

Please tell me all about your call on Winifred, which you said that you were going to make the afternoon you wrote. And please, oh please, dear Hilda, tell me the girl’s name! If you prefer I will not mention that you told it to me. I will keep it shut up in my heart, but I feel as if I must know it.
Mrs. Russell sends her best love, and so do I, and please pass it on to Richard to whom I will write in a few days.
